Centering activity - Setting the stage - Paired coding - Group Debrief # Centering Activity * Reena :-) ## Exit Ticket Results {.smaller} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](06-assess_braceros_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-1-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: # Setting the Stage - This week's focus is on data tidying and transformation - Using metadata from 90 interviews in the Bracero Archive that I scraped - Important to note that each row represents a person, a life, and a family impacted by the Bracero Program # Let's get Started - Find your pair - Open Posit # First Steps {.smaller} - Import Data - Load packages - You may need to install readxl using `install.packages("package name")`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(readxl) # for loading data library(tidyverse) # for tidying ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ::: # Load Data ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero <- read_excel("data/bracero_pull.xlsx") ``` ::: # Part II: Today's Goal - Understand data structure - Transform and tidy data for necessary questions - Explore and summarize patterns - Connect it to theoretical understandings of procedural justice ## Our data {.smaller} - 90 rows (interviews) - 6 variables (all `chr` type) - title = Person interviewed - subject = topic of interview - description = summary of interview - date = date of interview - identifier = link to original interview file - language = language interview was conducted in ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} glimpse(bracero) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Rows: 90 Columns: 6 $ title "Richard Hancock", "Pedro Cantor", "Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n", "‚Ä¶ $ subject "Do√±a Ana County Farm Bureau", "Bracero", "Bracero", "Brac‚Ä¶ $ description "Biographical Synopsis of Interviewee: Richard Hancock wa‚Ä¶ $ date "2003-04-21", "2005-07-27", "2006-05-22", "2005-09-01", "2‚Ä¶ $ identifier "https://braceroarchive.org/items/show/82;https://braceroa‚Ä¶ $ language "eng", "spa", "spa", "spa", "eng", "spa", "spa", "eng", "s‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ::: ## Variable Types {.smaller} We will work primarily with five types of variables in this course: - `chr` is character - `dbl` is double (number) - `int` is an integer - `dttm` is date-time - `fct` is factor Thoughts on what variables we may want to change the data types of? ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Rows: 90 Columns: 6 $ title "Richard Hancock", "Pedro Cantor", "Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n", "‚Ä¶ $ subject "Do√±a Ana County Farm Bureau", "Bracero", "Bracero", "Brac‚Ä¶ $ description "Biographical Synopsis of Interviewee: Richard Hancock wa‚Ä¶ $ date "2003-04-21", "2005-07-27", "2006-05-22", "2005-09-01", "2‚Ä¶ $ identifier "https://braceroarchive.org/items/show/82;https://braceroa‚Ä¶ $ language "eng", "spa", "spa", "spa", "eng", "spa", "spa", "eng", "s‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ::: # Transforming Data (Columns) {.smaller} - Four functions can change the *columns* of your data without affecting your *rows* - mutate(): creates new columns based on existing ones - select(): chooses what columns you want in your dataframe - rename(): changes the names of current columns - relocate(): changes the position of those columns ## mutate() function {.smaller} - We use the mutate function to create a new column `date_format`, using the `date` column. - In this case, we use the `as.Date()` function nested in the mutate function to change the `date` column's data type. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero |> mutate(date_format = as.Date(date)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 90 √ó 7 title subject description date identifier language date_format 1 Richard Hancock Do√±a A‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng 2003-04-21 2 Pedro Cantor Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2005-07-27 3 Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2006‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2006-05-22 4 Vincente Delgado Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2005-09-01 5 Inez Rios Intera‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng 2003-01-31 6 Manuel Enriquez Sa‚Ä¶ Bureau‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2003-02-06 7 Alberto Montes Gon‚Ä¶ Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2005-07-27 8 Ernesto Espino Son of‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng 2005-11-12 9 Jes√∫s Ort√≠z Torres Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2005-08-31 10 Jos√© G. Corral Son of‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2005-11-12 # ‚Ñπ 80 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## mutate() function (cont.) {.smaller} - We can also use mutate for creating new columns, and we can pair it with additional functions, such as ifelse statements. - `%in%c()` allows you to list multiple matches in the `subject` column. - Perhaps we were interested in creating a new column that defines whether an interview is from a bracero worker or not. - Note that if we wanted to create more than two groups, we might create a factor column and use the `case_match()` function, rather than an ifelse statement. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero |> mutate(subject_binary = ifelse(subject %in% c("bracero", "Bracero"), "Bracero", "Non-Bracero" )) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 90 √ó 7 title subject description date identifier language subject_binary 1 Richard Hancock Do√±a A‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng Non-Bracero 2 Pedro Cantor Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa Bracero 3 Asterio L√≥pez L‚Ä¶ Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2006‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa Bracero 4 Vincente Delgado Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa Bracero 5 Inez Rios Intera‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng Non-Bracero 6 Manuel Enriquez‚Ä¶ Bureau‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa Non-Bracero 7 Alberto Montes ‚Ä¶ Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa Bracero 8 Ernesto Espino Son of‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng Non-Bracero 9 Jes√∫s Ort√≠z Tor‚Ä¶ Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa Bracero 10 Jos√© G. Corral Son of‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa Non-Bracero # ‚Ñπ 80 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## select() function {.smaller} - Perhaps we'd like to remove the original `date` column from our dataframe. - `select()` can be used to select or deselect columns. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="|3|7|11"} # select column you don't want bracero |> select(-date) # select columns you do want bracero |> select(title, subject, description, date, identifier, language, date_format) # select columns in a row, except the column you don't want bracero |> select(title:description, identifier:date_format) ``` ::: ## rename() function {.smaller} - sometimes original column names aren't very descriptive, or they're too long. - the `rename()` function can help. - let's rename "title" to something more descriptive like "interviewee". ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero |> rename("interviewee" = "title") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 90 √ó 6 interviewee subject description date identifier language 1 Richard Hancock Do√±a Ana Coun‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng 2 Pedro Cantor Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 3 Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2006‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 4 Vincente Delgado Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 5 Inez Rios Interaction w‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng 6 Manuel Enriquez Savignac Bureau of Emp‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 7 Alberto Montes Gonz√°lez Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 8 Ernesto Espino Son of bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng 9 Jes√∫s Ort√≠z Torres Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 10 Jos√© G. Corral Son of a brac‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa # ‚Ñπ 80 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## relocate() function {.smaller} - Say we want the `identifier` column at the very end of the dataframe - `relocate` automatically puts the column at the front, so you have to specify `.after` or `.before`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero |> relocate(identifier, .after = language) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 90 √ó 6 title subject description date language identifier 1 Richard Hancock Do√±a Ana Coun‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ eng https://b‚Ä¶ 2 Pedro Cantor Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ spa https://b‚Ä¶ 3 Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2006‚Ä¶ spa https://b‚Ä¶ 4 Vincente Delgado Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ spa https://b‚Ä¶ 5 Inez Rios Interaction w‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ eng https://b‚Ä¶ 6 Manuel Enriquez Savignac Bureau of Emp‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ spa https://b‚Ä¶ 7 Alberto Montes Gonz√°lez Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ spa https://b‚Ä¶ 8 Ernesto Espino Son of bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ eng https://b‚Ä¶ 9 Jes√∫s Ort√≠z Torres Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ spa https://b‚Ä¶ 10 Jos√© G. Corral Son of a brac‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ spa https://b‚Ä¶ # ‚Ñπ 80 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## Put it together {.smaller} - We can put all of these data transformation actions together using the pipe `|>` function - line 1: creates new dataframe called `bracero_clean` - line 2: creates formatted date column called `date_format` - line 3: selects for all columns except for the old `date` column - line 4: renames the `title` column to as `interviewee` - line 5: moves the `indentifier` column to after the `date_format` column. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-line-numbers="1|2|3|4|5"} bracero_clean <- bracero |> mutate(date_format = as.Date(date)) |> select(-date) |> rename("interviewee" = "title") |> relocate(identifier, .after = date_format) ``` ::: # Exercise One - Starting with the `bracero` dataframe, code the following three actions using |> into a new dataframe called `bracero_ex1`: - mutate the `date`column to be in a 'year-month-date' format into a new column, called `date_format`. - hint: you may need to type `?as.Date()` into the console for help. - select the `title`, `date_format`, and `description` columns. - relocate the `date_format` column to be the first in the dataframe. # Transforming Data (Rows) - Moving on to rows! - `filter()` is a function that allows you to keep rows of interest (but won't change the order of your rows) - `arrange()` changes the order of your rows (but won't filter for anything) ## filter() function {.smaller} - Use the `filter()` function to select rows that correspond to values of interest. - Say we're interested in only interviews that are spoken in spanish: - use `==` to filter the language column for rows with a direct match (in this case "spa") ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero_clean |> filter(language == "spa") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 75 √ó 6 interviewee subject description language date_format identifier 1 Pedro Cantor Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-07-27 https://b‚Ä¶ 2 Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2006-05-22 https://b‚Ä¶ 3 Vincente Delgado Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-09-01 https://b‚Ä¶ 4 Manuel Enriquez Savignac Bureau ‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2003-02-06 https://b‚Ä¶ 5 Alberto Montes Gonz√°lez Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-07-27 https://b‚Ä¶ 6 Jes√∫s Ort√≠z Torres Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-08-31 https://b‚Ä¶ 7 Jos√© G. Corral Son of ‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-11-12 https://b‚Ä¶ 8 Eduardo De Santiago Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2003-03-03 https://b‚Ä¶ 9 Salvador Torres Beltr√°n Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2006-05-22 https://b‚Ä¶ 10 Luis Zamudio Villagomez Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-07-27 https://b‚Ä¶ # ‚Ñπ 65 more rows ``` ::: ::: ## filter() (cont.) {.smaller} - You can also combine multiple conditions: - `>` = greater than - `>=` = greater than or equal to - `<` = less than - `<=` less than or equal to - `==` equal to - `!=` does not equal - Can use `&` to combine conditions - `|` for or - Perhaps we're interested in interviews that took place after 2004 in English: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero_clean |> filter(date_format >= 2004-01-01 & language == "eng") ``` ::: ## filter() and str_detect() - We can also combine filter with the `str_detect()` function, to look for character matches. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero_clean |> filter(str_detect(interviewee, "Alberto")) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 √ó 6 interviewee subject description language date_format identifier 1 Alberto Montes Gonz√°lez Bracero "Biographica‚Ä¶ spa 2005-07-27 https://b‚Ä¶ 2 Alberto Magall√≥n Jim√©nez Bracero "Biographica‚Ä¶ spa 2005-07-28 https://b‚Ä¶ 3 Alberto Mendoza Torres bracero "Biographica‚Ä¶ spa 2003-09-26 https://b‚Ä¶ ``` ::: ::: ## arrange() - `arrange()` sorts your rows based on the values in the columns. - If you sort more than one row, it will sort the first variable, and the others will be used to "break ties" - including `desc()` will sort your column values big to small. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero_clean |> arrange(date_format, interviewee) ``` ::: # Exercise Two {.smaller} 1. Filter the `bracero_clean` dataframe for any interviews that took place before 2005 with an interviewee whose name includes "Guadalupe". 2. Arrange the bracero_clean data frame in descending order by `date_format`. What was the date, how many interviews took place on the that date, and who is listed first? 3. Filter the `bracero_clean` dataframe for any description columns that mention "California". How many interviewees are there? # Grouping Data ## group_by() function {.smaller} - `group_by()` function is really helpful for dividing your data into groups for analysis. - `group_by()` function does not change your data, but will change subsequent operations if you use them in tandem with a `group_by()` - You can also group by multiple columns. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero_clean |> group_by(language) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 90 √ó 6 # Groups: language [2] interviewee subject description language date_format identifier 1 Richard Hancock Do√±a An‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng 2003-04-21 https://b‚Ä¶ 2 Pedro Cantor Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-07-27 https://b‚Ä¶ 3 Asterio L√≥pez Le√≥n Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2006-05-22 https://b‚Ä¶ 4 Vincente Delgado Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-09-01 https://b‚Ä¶ 5 Inez Rios Interac‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng 2003-01-31 https://b‚Ä¶ 6 Manuel Enriquez Savignac Bureau ‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2003-02-06 https://b‚Ä¶ 7 Alberto Montes Gonz√°lez Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-07-27 https://b‚Ä¶ 8 Ernesto Espino Son of ‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ eng 2005-11-12 https://b‚Ä¶ 9 Jes√∫s Ort√≠z Torres Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-08-31 https://b‚Ä¶ 10 Jos√© G. Corral Son of ‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ spa 2005-11-12 https://b‚Ä¶ # ‚Ñπ 80 more rows ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # bracero_clean |> # group_by(date_format, language) ``` ::: ## summarize() - `summarize()` is often used in tandem with the `group_by()` function to calculate summary statistic(s) for a group. - In this case we are grouping the `bracero_clean` dataframe by the values in the `language` column, and summarizing the number of interviews using the `n()` function in a new column called `n_interviews`. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero_clean |> group_by(language) |> summarize(n_interviews = n()) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 √ó 2 language n_interviews 1 eng 15 2 spa 75 ``` ::: ::: ## slice {.smaller} - `slice_` functions help select a subset of rows - slice_head(n = 5) will take the first five rows of the data - slice_tail(n = 5) will take the last five rows of the data - slice_min(x, n = 5) will take the five rows of data with the lowest values for column x. - slice_max(x, n = 5) will take the five rows of data with the highest values for column x. - slice_sample(n = 5) will select 5 random rows of data. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} bracero |> slice_sample(n = 15) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 15 √ó 6 title subject description date identifier language 1 Liborio Santiago P√©rez Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2002‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 2 Maurilio Salcido Hern√°ndez Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 3 Miguel J√°quez L√≥pez Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 4 Roberto Ponce Covarrubias Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 5 Jos√© G. Corral Son of a ‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 6 Socorro O. P√©rez Clerk typ‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng 7 Ismael Z. Nicol√°s Osorio Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 8 Manuel Enriquez Savignac Bureau of‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 9 Jos√© Isidro Vida√±a Canales Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 10 Gregorio Flores P√©rez Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 11 Sam S√°nchez Public He‚Ä¶ "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng 12 Andy Imutan Activist "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2005‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ eng 13 Guadalupe Garc√≠a Gonz√°lez Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2006‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 14 Jos√© Guadalupe Blanco Ortega Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2003‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa 15 Aurelio Mar√≠n Luna Bracero "Biographi‚Ä¶ 2006‚Ä¶ https://b‚Ä¶ spa ``` ::: ::: # Exercise Three {.smaller} 1. How many Braceros were interviewed in this dataset (i.e., Bracero is the subject)? Use a `group_by` function to count. - Hint: R is case-sensitive. 2. How many non-braceros were interviewed in this dataset? 3. Using the `subject` column, can you create a new factor column called `topic_group`that collapses the subject column into 3-5 categories? - Hint: use `mutate()`, and `case_match()` to classify the groups into a new column called `topic_group`, I've given you a start! 4. Are there any interesting patterns in language spoken among your `topic_group` column in the `bracero_clean` dataframe? Use a `group_by` and `summarize` function to calculate. # Exercise Four 1. Explore the Bracero Archives and listen to at least one interview. - Note that most all bracero interviews are conducted in spanish, if you're interested in a perspective from an english-speaking bracero, I would suggest the interview with [Mr. Cris Luna](https://braceroarchive.org/items/show/138), a Bracero from Ozuluama, Veracruz, Mexico. Answer questions 2 and 3 using this week's readings.
